text: to Revelation chapter number two. And this evening, as you see in the bulletin, as I mentioned at the close of the service this morning, we'll be dealing with the church at Thyatira, but only the first aspect of the church. And we'll look at just a couple of verses this evening. The city of Thyatira was a relatively small city, but it was wealthy. And they were well known for several different things, but most, I guess, famous, if you will. They were known for their wool and for their dyeing industry. And Acts 16 and verse 14, we're told about Lydia. And she was a seller of purple, and she was from the city of Thyatira. And we read about that in Acts 16 and verse 14. It gives us a little bit of insight with regard to some of the commercial trade and what they were very well known for. The city was located approximately 35 miles southeast of Pergamos. Of course, we dealt with, last Sunday evening, the message to the church at Pergamos. We find that the Lord, as we begin studying this particular letter to the church at Thyatira, once again, is going to emphasize a particular aspect about his nature to this church. In verse 18, the Bible says, and unto the angel of the church in Thyatira write, these things saith the Son of God, who hath his eyes like unto a flame of fire, and his feet are like fine brass. And really, that reminds us of what had been said in chapter one, verses 14 and 15. And when we see these two references, to his eyes like unto a flame of fire, and his feet are like fine brass, it reminds us that he sees all and he judges all. And there is nothing hidden from our God. There's nothing in your life, my life, or anyone else's life that is hidden from God. As much as man has tried to cover their sin, as much as man has tried to hide things from God, the reality is that God knows all things. God knows the thoughts of your heart, of my heart. And we are reminded that not only does he see all, but he judges all. He is the judge of the entire earth. We find that as we look at this letter to the church in Thyatira, it is this letter that is the longest of the seven letters that we read in Revelation 2 and Revelation 3. And we find that with the length of this letter, that's one of the reasons that we're only gonna focus tonight on just a couple of the verses, because we'll have a multi-part as we try to make our way through this particular letter. It's very interesting as we've studied through these letters up to this point, and I'll say it my way of introduction, we begin to think about a church under the evaluation, the examination of the Lord Jesus Christ, who is the head of the church. We find that he's examining, he's evaluating the ministries of these particular churches. Of course, we understand that they are literal churches that existed at the time of the writing. They are local bodies of believers. And we find that as he would go through the process of having these letters sent and evaluating the ministry, that you find many times, and it's quite interesting as we look at the church in Thyatira, that there's really almost a direct opposite with what you find here in the church at Thyatira versus the church in Ephesus. We find that the church in Ephesus was, they could not, they would not allow for any type of evil. They were very sound with regard to their doctrine and what have you, but they had left their first love. They had departed from their first works. And yet we find the church in Thyatira where they're growing in their works and they're being commended for these things, but yet doctrinal error is coming in. When we begin to think about these things as you look through these letters, we really are reminded that the goal in ministry is to be balanced. And how important it is that we're balanced in our own lives individually in our homes, but in our churches, where we have the right position and the right disposition. We believe the right thing and we behave the right way. We are doing what God's called us to do while holding firm to the truth that God has given to us. And so often, as I mentioned last week, with regard to the temptation for compromise, so often there's some area that we begin to falter in and we might keep things going well here and we're staying sound here, but we're compromising here. And there's this need for balance in ministry and that we understand that everything is important. There's not certain things to say, we're just gonna focus on these things and let all these things slide. We're gonna find ourselves in trouble. And we find here this evening that as the Lord Jesus Christ is having this letter written to the church in Thyatira, he says in verse 19, as we have noted in each of these letters, I know thy works. Notice with me the entirety of verse 19. He says, I know thy works and charity and service and faith and thy patience and thy works. He says it a second time. And notice this last phrase of verse number 19 and the last to be more than the first. As we begin to examine that phrase at the end of verse 19, it would seem as if the Lord is saying to this church in these five areas that are mentioned in verse 19 that they were growing, that they were progressing in these particular areas because he says that the last is more than the first. It's interesting because again, as I mentioned already to the church at Ephesus, in verse number five of chapter two, the Bible says, remember therefore from whence thou art fallen and repent. And notice where it says, and do the first works or else I will come unto thee quickly and will remove thy candlestick out of his place except thou repent. As we look at the church in Thyatira, he says, I know thy works and charity and service and faith and thy patience and thy works and the last to be more than the first. Is that what first Peter two verse number two says? When Peter writes in second Peter chapter three in verse 18, but grow in grace and knowledge of our Lord and savior Jesus Christ. And the Christian life is about growth. And the thing that's amazing about the Christian life is that your growth and my growth is not going to be restricted to some growth chart that somebody provides. No, we understand that we can grow as quickly as we wanna grow. We can be as close to God as we wanna be. We can be as spiritual as we wanna be. And the reality is that as Paul is writing to the believers in the book of Hebrews, he tells us for in the time that you ought to be teachers. Why does he use that phraseology in Hebrews five in verse number 12? Because they should have been growing. And if the church is made up of individual saved and baptized believers who have voluntarily joined themselves together for the carrying out of the great commission, if that is a simple definition this evening of the church, the local church, and we believe that as Christians were to be growing, then we could easily say this tonight that churches should be growing. Churches should be growing. Here's one of the problems with growth. There's been such an emphasis over the last couple of generations with regard to church growth being strictly numerical. And there's this numerical focus and emphasis on church growth. Let me be quick to say this, I'm all for the church growing numerically. It means that you're reaching people. It means that you're investing in people and I'm all for the church growing numerically, but the reality is that a church needs to be growing spiritually. It's not one or the other, it should be both. A church should be growing numerically and a church should be growing spiritually. And so a church ought to be growing. The church in Thyatira, as we look at verse number 19, it seems as if they're growing and we'll reference these five areas.
